question: <image 1> Is it possible to cultivate in a lab the black fungus, commonly known as sooty mould, that typically grows on leaf surfaces, even though its name is indicative of a condition and not a distinct fungal species?
options: ['Some of the fungi can be grown in culture but not all', "Don't know and don't want to guess", 'They will only grow if honey dew is included in the media', 'Yes, the fungi that make up the sooty mould family can be grown in culture.', 'It is not possible to grow these fungi in culture']
description: The image shows a close-up view of several leaves on a plant. The leaves have a green color with prominent veins running through them. Some of the leaves exhibit patches of black discoloration, which appears to be a type of fungal growth commonly known as sooty mold. The black patches are irregularly shaped and scattered across the surface of the leaves. The surrounding environment includes more green leaves and some branches, indicating that the plant is growing outdoors in a natural setting.
